an9.35:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāvī pabbateyyā bālā abyattā akhettaññū akusalā visame pabbate carituṃ.
an9.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a mountain cow who was foolish, incompetent, unskillful, and lacked common sense when roaming on rugged mountains.

an9.35:1.3.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ agatapubbañceva disaṃ gaccheyyaṃ, akhāditapubbāni ca tiṇāni khādeyyaṃ, apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni piveyyan’ti.
an9.35:1.3.eng: ‘Why don’t I go somewhere I’ve never been before? I could eat grass and drink water that I’ve never tried before.’

an9.35:1.4.pli: Sā purimaṃ pādaṃ na suppatiṭṭhitaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā pacchimaṃ pādaṃ uddhareyya.
an9.35:1.4.eng: She’d take a step with a fore-hoof; but before it was properly set down, she’d lift up a hind-hoof.

an9.35:1.5.pli: Sā na ceva agatapubbaṃ disaṃ gaccheyya, na ca akhāditapubbāni tiṇāni khādeyya, na ca apītapubbāni pānīyāni piveyya;
an9.35:1.5.eng: She wouldn’t go somewhere she’d never been before, or eat grass and drink water that she’d never tried before.

an9.35:1.6.eng: And she’d never return safely to the place she had started from.

an9.35:1.7.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ agatapubbañceva disaṃ gaccheyyaṃ, akhāditapubbāni ca tiṇāni khādeyyaṃ, apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni piveyyan’ti tañca padesaṃ na sotthinā paccāgaccheyya.

an9.35:1.9.pli: Tathā hi sā, bhikkhave, gāvī pabbateyyā bālā abyattā akhettaññū akusalā visame pabbate carituṃ.
an9.35:1.9.eng: Because that mountain cow was foolish, incompetent, unskillful, and lacked common sense when roaming on rugged mountains.

an9.35:1.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu bālo abyatto akhettaññū akusalo vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an9.35:1.10.eng: In the same way, some foolish, incompetent, unskillful mendicant, lacking common sense, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.35:1.11.pli: so taṃ nimittaṃ na āsevati na bhāveti na bahulīkaroti na svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:1.11.eng: But they don’t cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis; they don’t ensure it is properly stabilized.

an9.35:2.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:2.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.’

an9.35:2.3.pli: So na sakkoti vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an9.35:2.3.eng: But they’re not able to enter and remain in the second absorption.

an9.35:2.5.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:2.5.eng: ‘Why don’t I, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.’

an9.35:2.6.pli: So na sakkoti vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an9.35:2.6.eng: But they’re not able to enter and remain in the first absorption.

an9.35:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu ubhato bhaṭṭho ubhato parihīno, seyyathāpi sā gāvī pabbateyyā bālā abyattā akhettaññū akusalā visame pabbate carituṃ’.
an9.35:2.7.eng: This is called a mendicant who has slipped and fallen from both sides. They’re like the mountain cow who was foolish, incompetent, unskillful, and lacking in common sense when roaming on rugged mountains.

an9.35:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāvī pabbateyyā paṇḍitā byattā khettaññū kusalā visame pabbate carituṃ.
an9.35:3.1.eng: Suppose there was a mountain cow who was astute, competent, skillful, and used common sense when roaming on rugged mountains.

an9.35:3.3.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ agatapubbañceva disaṃ gaccheyyaṃ, akhāditapubbāni ca tiṇāni khādeyyaṃ, apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni piveyyan’ti.
an9.35:3.3.eng: ‘Why don’t I go somewhere I’ve never been before? I could eat grass and drink water that I’ve never tried before.’

an9.35:3.4.pli: Sā purimaṃ pādaṃ suppatiṭṭhitaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā pacchimaṃ pādaṃ uddhareyya.
an9.35:3.4.eng: She’d take a step with a fore-hoof; and after it was properly set down, she’d lift up a hind-hoof.

an9.35:3.5.pli: Sā agatapubbañceva disaṃ gaccheyya, akhāditapubbāni ca tiṇāni khādeyya, apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni piveyya.
an9.35:3.5.eng: She’d go somewhere she’d never been before, and eat grass and drink water that she’d never tried before.

an9.35:3.6.eng: And she’d return safely to the place she had started from.

an9.35:3.7.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ agatapubbañceva disaṃ gaccheyyaṃ, akhāditapubbāni ca tiṇāni khādeyyaṃ, apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni piveyyan’ti tañca padesaṃ sotthinā paccāgaccheyya.

an9.35:3.9.pli: Tathā hi sā, bhikkhave, gāvī pabbateyyā paṇḍitā byattā khettaññū kusalā visame pabbate carituṃ.
an9.35:3.9.eng: Because that mountain cow was astute, competent, skillful, and used common sense when roaming on rugged mountains.

an9.35:3.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu paṇḍito byatto khettaññū kusalo vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:3.10.eng: In the same way, some astute, competent, skillful mendicant, using common sense, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.35:3.11.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:3.11.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:4.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:4.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.’

an9.35:4.3.pli: So dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā … dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:4.3.eng: Without charging at the second absorption, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption.

an9.35:4.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:4.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:5.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihareyyaṃ sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeyyaṃ yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti—upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:5.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, with the fading away of rapture, enter and remain in the third absorption, where I will meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.”’

an9.35:5.3.pli: So tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno pītiyā ca virāgā … tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:5.3.eng: Without charging at the third absorption, with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption.

an9.35:5.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:5.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:6.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:6.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.’

an9.35:6.3.pli: So catutthaṃ jhānaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:6.3.eng: Without charging at the fourth absorption, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption.

an9.35:6.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:6.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:7.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:7.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.’

an9.35:7.3.pli: So ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:7.3.eng: Without charging at the dimension of infinite space, with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.35:7.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:7.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:8.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:8.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that “consciousness is infinite”, enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

an9.35:8.3.pli: So viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:8.3.eng: Without charging at the dimension of infinite consciousness, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an9.35:8.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:8.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:9.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:9.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.’

an9.35:9.3.pli: So ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:9.3.eng: Without charging at the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

an9.35:9.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:9.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:10.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:10.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

an9.35:10.3.pli: So nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:10.3.eng: Without charging at the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an9.35:10.4.pli: So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti svādhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhāti.
an9.35:10.4.eng: They cultivate, develop, and make much of that basis, ensuring that it’s properly stabilized.

an9.35:11.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.35:11.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.’

an9.35:11.3.pli: So saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ anabhihiṃsamāno sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.35:11.3.eng: Without charging at the cessation of perception and feeling, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

an9.35:12.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu taṃ tadeva samāpattiṃ samāpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi, tassa mudu cittaṃ hoti kammaññaṃ.
an9.35:12.1.eng: When a mendicant enters and emerges from all these attainments, their mind becomes pliable and workable.

an9.35:12.2.pli: Mudunā kammaññena cittena appamāṇo samādhi hoti subhāvito.
an9.35:12.2.eng: With a pliable and workable mind, their immersion becomes limitless and well developed.

an9.35:12.3.pli: So appamāṇena samādhinā subhāvitena yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an9.35:12.3.eng: They extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:13.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhaveyyaṃ—ekopi hutvā bahudhā assaṃ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko assaṃ …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteyyan’ti,
an9.35:13.1.eng: They might wish: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again … controlling my body as far as the realm of divinity.’

an9.35:13.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an9.35:13.2.eng: They are capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:14.1.eng: They might wish: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.’

an9.35:14.2.eng: They are capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:15.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.1.eng: They might wish: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with my mind.

an9.35:15.2.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.2.eng: May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”,

an9.35:15.3.pli: vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ vītarāgaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.3.eng: and mind without greed as “mind without greed”;

an9.35:15.4.pli: sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ sadosaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.4.eng: mind with hate as “mind with hate”,

an9.35:15.5.pli: vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ vītadosaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.5.eng: and mind without hate as “mind without hate”;

an9.35:15.6.pli: samohaṃ vā cittaṃ samohaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an9.35:15.6.eng: mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”,

an9.35:15.7.eng: and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”;

an9.35:15.17.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajāneyyan’ti,

an9.35:15.18.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an9.35:15.18.eng: They are capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:16.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyan’ti,
an9.35:16.1.eng: They might wish: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I recollect my many past lives, with features and details.’

an9.35:16.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an9.35:16.2.eng: They’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:17.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyan’ti
an9.35:17.1.eng: They might wish: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.’

an9.35:17.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an9.35:17.2.eng: They’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an9.35:18.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
an9.35:18.1.eng: They might wish: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an9.35:18.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane”ti.
an9.35:18.2.eng: They’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.”

an9.36:1.1.pli: “Paṭhamampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I say that the first absorption is a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.2.pli: dutiyampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.2.eng: The second absorption is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.3.pli: tatiyampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.3.eng: The third absorption is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.4.pli: catutthampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.4.eng: The fourth absorption is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.5.pli: ākāsānañcāyatanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.5.eng: The dimension of infinite space is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.6.pli: viññāṇañcāyatanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.6.eng: The dimension of infinite consciousness is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.7.pli: ākiñcaññāyatanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.7.eng: The dimension of nothingness is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.8.pli: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi;
an9.36:1.8.eng: The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:1.9.pli: saññāvedayitanirodhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi.
an9.36:1.9.eng: The cessation of perception and feeling is also a basis for ending the defilements.

an9.36:2.1.pli: ‘Paṭhamampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmī’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an9.36:2.1.eng: ‘The first absorption is a basis for ending the defilements.’

an9.36:2.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.36:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.36:2.3.eng: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.36:2.4.pli: So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṃ vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati.
an9.36:2.4.eng: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

an9.36:2.5.eng: They turn their mind away from those things,

an9.36:2.6.pli: So tehi dhammehi cittaṃ paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṃ upasaṃharati:
an9.36:2.6.eng: and apply it to freedom from death:

an9.36:2.7.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an9.36:2.7.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an9.36:2.8.pli: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti.
an9.36:2.8.eng: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.

an9.36:2.9.pli: No ce āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an9.36:2.9.eng: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an9.36:4.1.eng: ‘The second absorption is also a basis for ending the defilements.’ …

an9.36:4.2.eng: ‘The third absorption is also a basis for ending the defilements.’ …

an9.36:6.1.pli: ‘Ākāsānañcāyatanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmī’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.

an9.36:6.3.eng: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.36:6.6.eng: and apply it to freedom from death:

an9.36:10.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, yāvatā saññāsamāpatti tāvatā aññāpaṭivedho.
an9.36:10.1.eng: And so, mendicants, penetration to enlightenment extends as far as attainments with perception.

an9.36:10.2.pli: Yāni ca kho imāni, bhikkhave, nissāya dve āyatanāni—
an9.36:10.2.eng: But the two dimensions that depend on these—

an9.36:10.3.pli: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti ca saññāvedayitanirodho ca, jhāyīhete, bhikkhave, samāpattikusalehi samāpattivuṭṭhānakusalehi samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā sammā akkhātabbānīti vadāmī”ti.
an9.36:10.3.eng: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the cessation of perception and feeling—are properly explained by meditators who are skilled in these attainments and skilled in emerging from them, after they’ve entered them and emerged from them.”
